title: 109_s1739
content: SECTION 1. RELEASE OR DETENTION OF A MATERIAL WITNESS. Amendments to Title 18 include the arrest of a material witness if there is probable cause to believe their testimony is material and they have failed to appear after being served with a summons or subpoena. A judicial officer may waive the summons requirement if it is likely the person will flee. A judicial officer may waive the summons or subpoena requirement if clear and convincing evidence shows that the person may flee or their appearance cannot be adequately secured. A warrant for a material witness must contain the witness's name or a description, specify the need for their testimony in a criminal case or grand jury proceeding, command their arrest, and inform them of their rights. A warrant for a material witness in a criminal case or grand jury proceeding must be signed by a judicial officer, command the witness's arrest, and inform them of their right to counsel. Upon arrest, the officer must show the warrant to the witness. Upon arrest, an officer must show the warrant to the material witness. If the officer does not possess the warrant at the time of arrest, they must inform the witness of its existence and purpose, and provide it upon request. After executing the warrant, the officer must return it to the judicial officer. After executing a warrant, an officer must return it to the judicial officer. An unexecuted warrant can be canceled by a judicial officer upon request. A material witness arrested must be brought before a judicial officer without delay. The initial appearance can be in the district of arrest or an adjacent district for promptness. The initial appearance of a material witness arrested must be in the district of arrest or an adjacent district for promptness. At this appearance, a judicial officer must inform the witness of the warrant, their rights, and provide an opportunity to retain counsel. Upon the appearance before a judicial officer, a material witness arrested pursuant to a warrant must be informed of their rights, allowed to consult with counsel, and either released or detained as ordered by the judicial officer. If the initial appearance occurs in a different district from where the warrant was issued, the witness may be transferred to that district. Upon appearance before a judicial officer, a material witness arrested under a warrant must be released or detained based on the officer's order. The witness can be released on personal recognizance, with an unsecured appearance bond, or on specified conditions unless there is clear evidence that their release won't ensure their appearance. If a material witness cannot reasonably assure their appearance, they may be detained for up to 5 days or until their testimony can be secured by deposition or court appearance. If a material witness cannot assure their appearance, a judicial officer may order their detention for up to 5 days or until their testimony can be secured by deposition or court appearance. The detention period can be extended for additional 5-day periods upon motion of a party. The detention of a material witness can be extended for up to 5 days or until their testimony can be secured. The total detention period may not exceed 30 days for a criminal case or 10 days for a grand jury proceeding. A motion must demonstrate good cause for the need to detain the witness. A motion must show good cause for why a material witness's testimony couldn't be obtained through deposition or court appearance in the previous 5 days. Factors like the witness's history and challenges to the warrant can be considered when deciding on release or detention. Release and detention orders must meet specific requirements. The release order must comply with specific requirements, while a detention order must also meet certain criteria, including holding a material witness separately from individuals charged with criminal offenses and under the least restrictive conditions possible. The Attorney General is required to submit an annual report to the Judiciary Committees of the Senate and House of Representatives on the use of this section by the United States Government. The Attorney General must provide an annual report to the Judiciary Committees of the Senate and House of Representatives on the use of warrants under subsection (a), including the number sought, granted or denied, material witnesses arrested, reasons for testimony not secured, and average detention days. Rule 46(h) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure is amended to address supervising detention pending trial. The amendment to Rule 46(h) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure requires the court to supervise the detention of defendants awaiting trial and material witnesses to eliminate unnecessary detention. The Attorney General must provide an annual report on the use of warrants under subsection (a), including the number of warrants sought, granted or denied, reasons for testimony not secured, and the average detention days for material witnesses.
